comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
Anti-War Rally at "The Cottage" in Union Square, New York City, August 8, 1914. 
[World War I had just broken out in Europe.]

"Suffragettes" had rallied there on May 2, 1914:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5169603438/]
Workers' rally a day earlier (May Day), 1914:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5669473837/]
Lincoln Steffens harangued an IWW crowd on April 11, 1914:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5169601930/]
William Jennings Bryan spoke two years before, on April 20, 1912:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2515741737/]

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:

Yes, it is! We will add to the caption when we update.  Thanks!

comment._content:

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Cornelius "Con" Lehane, an Irishman and a Socialist orator, immigrated to the United States in 1913. In 1917, after the U. S. entered World War I, Lehane was imprisoned for opposing the war effort. He died in 1919. Wikipedia on Con Lehane: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Con_Lehane_(socialist)
